summary: An FBI Miami Division memorandum requesting scanning and automation assistance from the Document Conversion Laboratory for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez, former house manager to Jeffrey Epstein, attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims rather than turn it over to authorities.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He allegedly came into possession of an address book containing names and telephone numbers of potential additional underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Identified as the employer of Alfredo Rodriguez and the central figure in a child prostitution case. The address book in Rodriguez's possession is believed to contain information related to his underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein during his employment.
Rodriguez possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's underage victims and attempted to sell it, obstructing justice in Epstein's case.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Telephone records timeframe
events.description: Telephone records were generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 2010) for the investigation.

events.title: Request for document scanning
events.description: FBI Miami requests the Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and automate telephone records for the Rodriguez/Epstein investigation for incorporation into the Telephone Application (TA) repository.

locations: Winchester, Virginia 22602 (DocLab - Telephone Application Audit Processing Team, Federal Bureau of Investigation, 170 Marcel Drive)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book containing names and telephone numbers believed to belong to additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell the address book to an Undercover Employee (UCE) instead of turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.

The FBI was processing telephone records (from 2001 onward) related to the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims, for incorporation into its investigative Telephone Application (TA) repository.
The document is an internal FBI request for technical scanning and data formatting assistance to support the investigation into Rodriguez's obstruction.
